page.title: 09Footpaths in Knockholt
page.content: Being entirely rural the area abounds in footpaths lined by trees and hedges or small copses or skirting farmland. Access is usually by gate or stile with a request to respect the land and not to damage crops or remove wild flowers. The footpaths provide a means of commuinication between houses and farms, and recreation, in that, people are able to enjoy the countryside. School parties gain valuable knowledge about farming and the enviroment by using these paths. Local horses are exercised along them - also those brought in by horse box from less rural areas. Hikers enjoy not only the lesser paths, but the well used and ever popular{"North Downs Way"}on the crest of the Downs going from Farnham to Canterbury and Rochester, and the "Pilgrims Way" at the foot of the Downs.
